variant.question: The take-off distance required increases...

options.text: due to downhill slope because of the smaller angle of attack.
due to slush on the runway.
due to lower gross mass at take-off.
due to head wind because of the drag augmentation.

variant.question: You are planning to fly a VFR sight-seeing flight during the day with a paying passenger. During the take-off climb out, which of the following most accurately describes the lateral obstacle clearance.

options.text: 90 m until 600 m after the departure end of Runway (DER) then 150 m
35 ft
You must look out of the cockpit to visually identify and avoid abstacles
50 ft

variant.question: A pilot has become accustomed to landing on long runways, with a high approach speed. Which of the following could happen if the pilot now attempts to land on a short runway using this same technique?

options.text: A normal landing.
The aircraft will have too much kinetic energy, and might overshoot the runway.
The landing will be better than usual.
The aircraft will not have enough kinetic energy, and might undershoot the runway.

variant.question: An aircraft has two certified landing flaps positions, 25° and 35°. If a pilot chooses 25° instead of 35°, the aircraft will have:

options.text: a reduced landing distance and better go-around performance.
a reduced landing distance and degraded go-around performance.
an increased landing distance and degraded go-around performance.
an increased landing distance and better go-around performance.

variant.question: The following runways are available: 07/250 and 01/190\. The wind is coming from 350°/25 degrees. Which runway should the pilot choose?
For a multi-engine aircraft in Performance Class B the minimum gross gradient of climb after a balked landing is:

On a twin engined piston aircraft with variable pitch propellers, for a given mass and altitude, the minimum drag speed is 125 kt and the holding speed (minimum fuel burn per hour) is 95 kt. The best rate of climb speed will be obtained for a speed...

options.text: between 95kt and 125kt
equal to 125kt
< 95kt
equal to 95kt

variant.question: The landing reference speed VREF has, in accordance with international requirements, the following margins above stall speed in landing configuration:

A light twin piston-engined aeroplane is cruising at 2000 ft when one of its engines fails. Whilst the pilot is performing the necessary actions to secure the engine, they observe that the aircraft is in a very slow descent, even with their operative engine at maximum continuous power. What is the reason for this?

options.text: The power required has reduced because drag is increased by the stationary propeller and the required control inputs to maintain direction, and the remaining engine has sufficient excess power.
The power available has reduced because the feathered propeller only produces a small amount of thrust compared to normal and therefore the power required is less than the power available.

The pilot must NOT have feathered the propeller of the failed engine, because ALL twin-engined aeroplanes that are certified in accordance with CS-23 must be able to climb within their environmental envelope.
The increased drag from the propeller of the failed engine and the required control inputs to maintain direction mean that the power from the remaining engine is insufficient to maintain altitude.

variant.question: The effect that a tailwind has on the value of the maximum endurance speed is:

options.text: none.
that the IAS must be decreased.
that a tailwind only affects the holding speed.
that the IAS must be increased.

variant.question: Consider a climb with a piston engine aeroplane. What will happen to the fuel flow if the pilot maintains the same power setting?

options.text: With increasing altitude air density decreases, therefore less fuel is required for combustion, so the fuel flow decreases.
With increasing altitude air density decreases and the power output of the engine decreases. This has to be compensated for by an increased fuel flow.
The temperature decreases and thereby over-compensates for the decreasing air density which is caused by the decreasing pressure. This results in a decreasing fuel flow.
The temperature decreases and thereby compensates for the decreasing air density which is caused by the decreasing pressure. Therefore the fuel flow remains the same.

variant.question: The critical engine of a multi-engined, propeller-driven aeroplane is the one whose failure would result in the most adverse effect on the aeroplane’s...

options.text: endurance.
maximum altitude.
fuel consumption.
handling and performance characteristics.

variant.question: What does VREF stand for? It is the speed in a specified:

options.text: Take-off configuration, at the point where the aeroplane climbs through 35 ft over the departure runway end, and is used to determine the take-off distance.
Landing configuration, at the point where the aeroplane descends through 50 ft, and is used to determine the landing distance for manual landings.
Take-off configuration, at the point where the aeroplane climbs through 50 ft over the departure runway end, and is used to determine the take-off distance.
Landing configuration, at the point where the aeroplane touches down on the runway, and is used to determine the landing distance for manual landings.

variant.question: Landing on a runway with 5 mm wet snow will:

options.text: decrease landing distance
increase landing distance
give a slightly reduced landing distance, due to increased impingement drag
not affect the landing distance

variant.question: For a piston-engine, at what altitude will it have the best endurance?

options.text: at service ceiling
about 15000 ft
at 15000 ft and more
about Mean Sea Level

variant.question: Which of the following requirements must be met by a MEP Performance Class B aircraft landing on dry runways? The actual landing distance shall be less than:

options.text: 1.43 x LDA.
0.6 x LDA.
0.7 x LDA.
1.15 x LDA.

variant.question:
Refer to figure or CAP698 file 2.1.  
What is the maximum estimated stall speed at 3 400 lbs?

options.text: 82 kt
71 kt
68 kt
59 kt

variant.question: Consider two different aircraft: a single-engine piston (SEP) producing 160 hp and a weight of 1300 lb, and a multi-engine piston (MEP) with two engines, each with 160 hp and a weight of 1900 lb. In the event of an engine failure, which of these aircraft would perform better?

options.text: The SEP aircraft is due to its higher power-to-weight ratio compared to the MEP.
The MEP aircraft due to its redundancy.
The SEP aircraft is due to its lighter weight and simpler configuration.
Both aircraft would perform similarly in the event of an engine failure.

variant.question: Assume a normal approach and landing with a class B aeroplane on a dry runway. Which of the following values shows the corresponding screen height?

options.text: 60 ft
50 ft
35 ft
100 ft

variant.question: You are flying an aircraft just after takeoff with a rate of climb of 500 ft/min, a TAS of 110 kt and no wind. You are at the 50 ft screen height, and there is a crane located 374 m ahead with a height of 9 m (over the runway elevation). What will be the obstacle clearance over the crane?
The rotation speed V**R** for normal utility single-engined landplanes (MTOM 5700 kg or less) must be the same as or faster than..

options.text: 1.10 VMC or 1.20 VS1, whichever is the greater.
1.05 VMC or 1.10 VS1, whichever is the greater.
VS1.

variant.question: How does a downslope runway affect the take off and landing performance of an aeroplane? It…

options.text: increases both the take off distance and the landing distance.
increases the take off distance, and decreases the landing distance.
decreases both the take off distance and the landing distance.
decreases the take off distance, and increases the landing distance.

variant.question: For a multi-engine aircraft in the class B performance category, what is the minimum all engine take-off climb gradient?

A high tension cable is located 1 NM from the DER (departure end of runway). Calculate the obstacle clearance for a class B single engine piston aircraft with the following conditions.

Climb Gradient: 5%   
 TAS: 133 kt   
 Tailwind Component: 10 kt   
 Cable Height: 104 ft   
 Height Difference = ((GD x climb gradient) / 100) x (TAS/GS)

options.text: 333 ft
229 ft
283 ft
179 ft

variant.question: In case of an obstacle that is within the obstacle accountability area but at some distance from the threshold, what flap setting is generally recommended?

options.text: Lower or no flap setting in order to achieve a greater climb gradient, accepting an increased ground-roll distance.
Higher flap setting in order to achieve a greater climb gradient, accepting an increased ground-roll distance.
Higher flap setting in order to achieve a shorter ground-roll distance and a greater climb gradient.
Lower or no flap setting in order to achieve a shorter ground-roll distance and a greater climb gradient.

variant.question:
Which of the following limitations apply to the Take-Off Distance (TOD) for Performance Class B aeroplanes operating from a dry runway?

1\. Without a stopway nor a clearway available, when multiplied by a factor of 1.25, it should NOT exceed the Take-Off Run Available (TORA).   
2\. When a stopway and/or clearway is available, it should NOT exceed the Take-Off Run Available (TORA).   
3\. With a stopway and/or clearway available, when multiplied by a factor of 1.15, it should NOT exceed the Take-Off Distance Available (TODA).   
4\. With a stopway and/or clearway available, when multiplied by a factor of 1.15, it should NOT exceed the Accelerate-Stop Distance Available (ASDA).

Based on actual conditions, an aeroplane has the following performance take-off mass limitations:

| FLAPS  | **0º**  | **10º** | **15º** |
| ------ | ------- | ------- | ------- |
| RUNWAY | 4100 kg | 4400 kg | 4600 kg |
| CLIMB  | 4700 kg | 4500 kg | 4200 kg |

Structural limits: take-off/landing/zero fuel: 4 300 kg

The Maximum Take-off Mass is:
In a twin engine piston aircraft with both engines rotating anti-clockwise, which is the critical engine if there is an engine failure after take-off?

options.text: Right engine.
Left or right engine, depending on the crosswind direction.
Left engine.
Left or right engine, depending on the runway track.

variant.question: Which of the following is correct concerning fuel consumption change at altitude of a propeller driven aeroplane?

options.text: Increases after VMP
Increases before VMP
Decreases after VMP
Decreases before VMP

variant.question: A pilot is operating a commercial air transport flight in accordance with EU Regulations (Part-CAT) in a twin-engine Performance Class B aeroplane. It is a sightseeing flight under VFR during the day. Considering the performance requirements for take-off and departure, which of the following options is correct regarding the horizontal extent of the flight path accountability area for this flight? The obstacle clearance accountability area...

options.text: commences at the end of the TODA and consists of a 90 m wide corridor along the flight path until the aeroplane reaches 50 ft above any obstacle.
commences at the assumed engine failure height and will gradually widen as the distance along the flight path increases.
is at least 60 m wide from the end of the TORA, gradually extending to a maximum 300m width along the planned flight path.
is effectively substituted by ensuring the weather conditions during operation are sufficient to visually navigate and avoid obstacles.

variant.question: For an SEP in the utility category, taking-off on a dry paved runway, the minimum value of V**R** is:

options.text: V2
The higher of 1.05VMCA or 1.2VSR
VS1
The higher of 1.1VMCA or 1.25VSR

variant.question: You are planning to fly to an aerodrome with a short runway. Which of the following conditions would be most restrictive for landing performance, and why?

options.text: High OAT due to high groundspeed.
High pressure due to high groundspeed.
High OAT due to high performance.
High pressure due to low performance.

variant.question: During a flight in a twin engine piston aeroplane under performance Class B, an engine failure is experienced. The pilot correctly performs the engine failure procedure. After setting the required thrust on the live engine, the pilot notices a continuous descent of 400 ft/min. Which of the following could have caused this?

options.text: Corrective rudder towards the dead engine has not been applied.
The live engine has not been feathered.
Corrective rudder towards the live engine has not been applied.
The dead engine has not been feathered.

variant.question: An aeroplane with reciprocating engines is flying at a constant angle of attack, mass and configuration. With increasing altitude the drag...

options.text: remains unchanged but the CAS increases.
increases at constant TAS.
remains unchanged but the TAS increases.
decreases and the CAS decreases too because of the lower air density.

variant.question: What are the implications on takeoff distances if a pilot increases thrust while aligning with the runway for a rolling takeoff?

options.text: TOD increases and ASD decreases
TOD and ASD decrease
TOD decreases and ASD increases
TOD and ASD increase

variant.question:
The following parameters affect the take-off ground run:

1.decreasing take-off mass   
2.increasing take-off mass   
3.increasing density   
4.decreasing density   
5.increasing flap setting   
6.decreasing flap setting   
7.increasing pressure altitude   
8.decreasing pressure altitude

Which parameters will decrease the take-off ground run?
Which of the following groups of conditions are the most favourable for take-off?

options.text: High airfield elevation, low temperature, high atmospheric pressure.
Low airfield elevation, low humidity, low temperature, high atmospheric pressure.
High airfield elevation, low humidity, high temperature, low atmospheric pressure.
Low airfield elevation, high temperature, low air density.

variant.question: What can be done to reduce any issues with asymmetric thrust in a twin engined propeller aircraft?

options.text: Place the engines further forwards on the wings.
Use counter-rotating propellers.
Have not more than 3 blades per propeller.
Place the engines a greater distance from the aircraft's centre line.

variant.question: The stalling speed or the minimum steady flight speed at which the aeroplane is controllable in landing configuration is abbreviated as...

options.text: VMC.
VSO.
VS.
VS1.

variant.question:
Refer to figure or CAP698 file 2.2.  
Given the following information, what is the rotation speed?

Outside Air Temperature ( OAT ): +25ºC  
Airport Pressure Altitude: 2500 ft  
Headwind component: 5 kt  
Take Off Mass: 3600 lb  
Flap setting: Approach

options.text: 75 kts
72 kts
77 kts
67 kts

variant.question: A pilot of a single-engined turbine aeroplane performs a Commercial Air Transport flight with passengers over land with no significant terrain and the cruise phase will be above a solid layer of cloud. The planned route must be such that, in the event of an engine failure, the aeroplane is able to glide...

options.text: from an altitude where the rate of climb is at least 300 fpm to a point 1000 ft above a runway, onto which a successful landing can be made.
to the point of landing on a suitable landing site and there should be no cloud below a height of 1000 ft agl.
to a point 1000 ft above a suitable landing area and the bottom of any solid cloud layer should be above the minimum safe altitude.
to a point 1000 ft above a runway onto which a successful emergency landing can be made and there should be no cloud below the minimum safe altitude.

variant.question: The combination of factors that most requires a low-angled flap setting for take-off is:

options.text: Low field elevation, no obstacles in the climb-out path, short runway and a low ambient temperature.
Low field elevation, close-in obstacles in the climb-out path, short runway and a high ambient temperature.
High field elevation, distant obstacles in the climb-out path, long runway and a high ambient temperature.
High field elevation, no obstacles in the climb-out path, low ambient temperature and short runway.

variant.question:
CS-23 defines a certain speed that must be reached on take-off. What speed is needed to correctly complete the following statement for item 2? For normal utility single-engined aeroplanes, the speed at 15 m (50 ft) above the take-off surface level must not be less than the higher of:

1\. a speed that is safe under all reasonably expected conditions, including turbulence and complete engine failure, or   
2\. ....
What effect will an increase in temperature and pressure altitude have on landing distance?

options.text: Landing distance increases due to increased air density.
Landing distance decreases due to increased air density.
Landing distance increases due to reduced air density.
Landing distance decreases due to reduced air density.

variant.question: How is take-off performance affected by using flaps 10° instead of flaps 5°?

options.text: Increased drag, stall speed decreases, ground roll increases.
Increased drag, stall speed increases, ground roll decreases.
Increased lift, stall speed increases, ground roll increases.
Increased lift, stall speed decrease, ground roll decreases.

variant.question: A pilot is planning to fly a light aircraft to an airport with a short runway, but which is long enough to land safely. The pilot is accustomed to landing at airports with long or very long runways and a mixture of small and large aeroplanes, where ATC often asks small aircraft to maintain a high approach speed to facilitate traffic flow. If the pilot flies as per their regular habit (with a high approach speed) when landing on the short runway…

options.text: the landing is more likely to be successful since the safety factors account for any inaccuracies in speed and touchdown point and therefore assure a safe landing.
the landing must be completed such that the aeroplane touches down before the normal touchdown point in order to allow for a greater braking distance after landing.
there is NO risk of runway excursion if the aeroplane touches down at the optimum touchdown point because the brakes are able to absorb greater energy.
there is a large risk of runway excursion as a higher-than-optimum approach speed increases the risk of floating with significant additional kinetic energy dissipating.

variant.question: A multi-engined performance class B aeroplane has a wingspan of less than 60 metres. What is the semi-width of the obstacle accountability area at a distance of D from the end of the TODA? A semi-width…

options.text: at the discretion of the pilot to ensure obstacle avoidance.
of at least 2 x wingspan plus 90 m, plus D x0.125.
of at least 1/2 x wingspan plus 90 m, plus D x0.125.
of at least 1/2 x wingspan plus 60 m, plus D x0.125.

variant.question: The strength of the yawing moment caused by an engine failure on a twin-engine aeroplane...

options.text: will be greater when the CG is located at the forward CG limit.
is independent of the location (fore or aft) of the CG.
will be greater when the CG is located at the aft CG limit.
will be greater when the CG is located halfway between the forward and aft CG limits.

variant.question: Which of the following options correctly describes the effects on aircraft performance of landing on wet or contaminated runways?

options.text: The effect of the increased wheel drag through the water is far greater than the loss of friction and reduced braking effect, therefore landing distances decrease.
Hydroplaning creates more drag on the wheels, which is evenly balanced by less effective brake drag, thus creating a similar deceleration force compared to a dry runway.
The lower effective braking force has a much greater effect on increasing the landing distance than the benefit of higher drag.
The coefficient of friction is dramatically increased, which reduces the maximum braking energy that can be applied, which increases the landing distance.

variant.question: Assuming the gross mass, altitude and airspeed remain unchanged, moving the Centre of Gravity from the forward safe limit to the aft safe limit:

options.text: increases the power required.
affects neither drag nor power required.
increases the induced drag.
decreases the induced drag and reduces the power required.

variant.question: A Performance Class B aeroplane is being used in a Commercial Air Transport operation. No stopway or clearway is available. The unfactored Take-Off Distance, specified in the AFM, shall not exceed the Take-Off Run Available TORA when multiplied by a factor of…
Changing the take-off flap setting from flap 15° to flap 5° will normally result in:

options.text: a shorter take-off distance and an equal climb.
a longer take-off distance and a better climb.
a shorter take-off distance and a better climb.
a better climb and an equal take-off distance.
